title: US service industries see job losses for the first time in 10 years as Trump's trade war rages
text:
Tiksa Negeri/Reuters

A gauge of service-sector jobs contracted for the first time since 2009 in September.

It was the latest sign that trade tensions have spilled over into broader parts of the economy.

IHS Markit said its survey on its service-sector employment index "is indicative of non-farm payroll growth falling below 100,000."

Visit the Markets Insider homepage for more stories.

A gauge of service-sector jobs contracted for the first time in nearly a decade in September, the latest sign that trade tensions have spilled over into broader parts of the economy.

The research group IHS Markit said on Monday that its index for services employment fell to 49.1 in September from 50.4 a month earlier, marking the first contraction and the lowest reading in the sector since December 2009. The overall PMI services index rose by less than expected but still indicated expansion.

"The survey indicates that businesses continue to struggle against the headwinds of trade worries and elevated uncertainty about the outlook," said Chris Williamson, the chief business economist at IHS Markit, adding, "Firms have become more risk averse and increasingly eager to cut costs."

The IHS Markit survey showed stabilization in factory activity, which had dipped into a recession this year. Its related measure of manufacturing activity rose by more than expected, to a five-month high of 51.

Hiring has cooled in recent months as businesses grapple with a series of tit-for-tat tariff disputes between President Donald Trump and the US's trading partners. Williamson said that "at current levels, the survey employment index is indicative of non-farm payroll growth falling below 100,000."

"Key to the recent deterioration has been a further spill-over of the trade-led slowdown in manufacturing to the service sector," Williamson said. "Inflows of new service sector business almost stalled in September to register the smallest rise since the survey began in 2009."

Last week, the World Trade Organization said that global trade in commercial services fell nearly 5 points from a year earlier, to below its long-term average of 100. The WTO gauge includes service sectors such as air travel and finance.
